title: Understanding Irregular Bleeding
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value:
A “typical” menstrual cycle varies from person to person.

Most cycles occur about every 21–35 days and bleeding usually lasts 3–8 days.

items: Periods that come more or less often than usual
Very heavy or very light periods
Periods that last much longer than usual

items.text: Periods that come more or less often than usual

sections.cardTitle: Common Causes of Irregular Vaginal Bleeding

content.value: Irregular bleeding can be linked to several conditions. Often the cause is not serious, but it should be checked — especially if the bleeding is new, heavy, or unusual for you.

items: Non-cancerous growths in the uterus that can cause heavy or irregular bleeding.
Tissue similar to the uterine lining grows outside the uterus and may affect bleeding patterns.
A hormone-related condition that can cause irregular or missed periods.
Fluctuations in oestrogen and progesterone levels can disrupt cycles.
Puberty or perimenopause - Hormone levels change during these times, which can make periods irregular.
Pregnancy - Early pregnancy can sometimes cause light bleeding. Any bleeding in pregnancy should be checked.
Intense exercise or major weight changes - Can affect hormone balance and menstrual cycles.
Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) - An infection of the reproductive organs that needs treatment.
Polyps or abnormal growths - Growths in the uterus or cervix that should be assessed.
Cancer (less common) - Irregular bleeding, especially after menopause or after sex, should always be checked.

content.value: Early assessment can help identify the cause and ensure you get the right care.

items.text: Bleeding between periods or after sex
Periods that are much heavier or longer than usual
Sudden or unexplained changes to your cycle

content.title: Need immediate help?
content.description:
Seek urgent medical advice if you have:

Very heavy bleeding (soaking through pads quickly or passing large clots)

Severe or worsening abdominal or pelvic pain

Dizziness, fainting, or feeling unwell with heavy bleeding

sections.cardTitle: What to Track Before Your Appointment

content.value: Bringing notes can help your doctor understand your symptoms more clearly.

steps:
Dates and length of your periods - Record when bleeding starts and ends.

How heavy the bleeding is - Note how often you change pads or tampons, whether you pass clots, or if bleeding affects daily activities.

Pain or other symptoms - Document pelvic pain, cramps, back pain, pain during sex, bowel or bladder symptoms, and when they occur in your cycle.

Bleeding between periods or after sex - Note when this happens and how often.

Lifestyle or health changes - Stress, exercise levels, weight changes, new medications, or contraception changes.

sections.cardTitle: What to Expect at Your Appointment

content.value: These assessments may help find the cause of irregular bleeding so the most suitable care can be planned.

items.title: Pelvic Examination
items.content: A physical exam may be offered to check for tenderness, swelling, or visible causes of bleeding. You can ask to stop at any time.

items.title: Ultrasound Scan
items.content: A scan (often transvaginal) that uses sound waves to look at the uterus and ovaries. It can help identify fibroids, cysts, thickened lining, or other structural causes.

items.title: Blood Tests
items.content: May include checks for anaemia, hormone levels, thyroid function, or other indicators depending on symptoms.

items.title: Cervical Smear (if due)
items.content: A routine screening test for cervical cell changes. It does not explain all causes of bleeding but may be done if you are due or have symptoms requiring it.

content.value: Treatment depends on the underlying cause of your irregular bleeding. Your doctor will recommend the most appropriate option based on your diagnosis.

items.title: Fibroids or polyps
items.description: Hormones, IUS, or procedures (e.g., hysteroscopic removal, embolisation)

items.title: Thickened womb lining
items.description: Hormonal treatment or biopsy depending on age/risk

items.title: Hormonal treatments
items.description:
Combined contraceptive pill

Progestogen-only methods

Hormonal coil (IUS)

Help regulate cycles and reduce bleeding.

items.title: NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen)
items.description: Can reduce pain and bleeding volume.

content.title: Procedures (If Medication Doesn’t Help)
content.description:
Hysteroscopy (to remove polyps or small fibroids)

Endometrial ablation (for heavy bleeding when pregnancy not desired)

Surgery (e.g., fibroid removal) in selected cases
